Award.AwardTitle: The Dissemination of Undergraduate Research Initiatives that Support Diversity and Inclusion in the Geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1
This project creates a partnership between the New York City College of Technology (City Tech), the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the National Center for Atmospheric Research, and Rutgers University that provides an opportunity for geoscience experts to come away from their busy routine activities (most of which do not allow the time and the setting for thoughtful reflection and engagement about the geosciences in general and about their own geoscience programs and innovations, in particular) and to huddle together for three days in a bid to create a geoscience support group, to exchange ideas about geoscience programs for URMs and marginalized groups, to document their tested strategies and best practices, and to forward-think about the shaping and the reshaping of a geoscience landscape that implements strategies and methodologies that encourages, embraces, and integrates diversity and inclusion.
The deliverables from this project will have transformative and sustainable effects on the geosciences. Not only will the project attract, add, and encourage a new cadre of geoscience experts to the geoscience writing and publication community, but it will also increase and proliferate best practices for engaging URMs and other marginalized groups in the geosciences and thereby potentially increase the successful participation of these neglected groups in the geosciences.

Part 2
This workshop seeks to take advantage of extant expertise in the atmospheric sciences to bolster the efforts related to workforce development and inclusive educational practices. Specifically, the project will: a) collect and compile geoscience research studies that will potentially advance knowledge about how best to engage URMs and other marginalized groups in the geosciences; b) provide hand-held guidance on how to prepare and submit a geoscience educational article that focuses on diversity and inclusion, and c) train and engage City Tech undergraduates in geoscience educational research. By providing expert guidance in writing and submitting geoscience educational research papers to peer-reviewed journals, articles developed at the workshop will be widely disseminated. Moreover, by posting the articles on City Tech's OpenLab site, they will be easily accessible to not only the geoscience community, but also to any group, institution, or person across the globe who has interest in cultivating diversity in the geosciences or in any other discipline. One of the highlights of this project is that it is replicable, adaptable, and adoptable. It may be scaled to involve more partners, more participants, and ultimately to produce more geoscience educational research articles that will help to inform how best to expand the geoscience tent as far as diversity and inclusion are concerned. Through this proposed project, geoscience practitioners who perhaps never would have documented their work, now have an opportunity to do so.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is continuing on a trajectory to become a more racially and ethnically diverse society; however, non-Hispanic Whites are projected to remain the largest ethnic group for the next four decades. Whilst the majority ethnic group is expected to become the minority and vice versa, the same trend is not expected and is not reflected in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) degree attainment or in the STEM workforce. Tested best practices for increasing the number of Underrepresented Minorities (URMs) and women in STEM include bridge programs, undergraduate research programs, mentoring, internships, and field experiences. However, formal research studies on diversity and inclusion in the geosciences are limited and/or too generalized. Therefore, this project’s writing workshop assisted in documenting more programs that have or are successfully supporting URMs and marginalized groups in the geosciences. The overall goal of the workshop, therefore, was to assist and to guide geoscience practitioners in producing publishable research studies that highlight effective undergraduate initiatives that support diversity and inclusion in the geosciences

 

Twenty (20) geoscience faculty and/or administrators were selected to attend a three-day workshop with the goal of completing a mini education research paper by the end of the workshop. The participants were invited to bring publishable quantitative or qualitative data and some preliminary results that focused on undergraduate underrepresented and/or marginalized group(s) in the geosciences. The undergraduate student population may include students who are URMs, first in their families to go to college (first generation), low income, veterans, disabled, and LGBT. As a complementary goal of the project, ten (10) URMs undergraduates were selected to assist the project participants as they participants wrote their geoscience education research paper. The ten undergraduates were thus given first-hand experience with the process of writing a STEM education paper; this experience was particularly beneficial to the ten student-helpers who themselves were interested in pursuing advanced degrees in STEM education.    

 

The workshop participants wrote mini-education research papers that focused on the following areas in the geosciences:

  • Strategies that are effective for increasing the participation of the aggregated and disaggregated minority and marginalized groups (i.e., African-Americans/Blacks, Hispanics/Latinos, Native Alaskan/Hawaiians, Asian Pacific Islanders, first generation, low incomes, veterans, females, and LGBTs);
  • Programming components that increase the success of underrepresented minorities in STEM undergraduates who graduate with geoscience degrees, attain geoscience occupations, and/or enter graduate schools;
  • Program structure of undergraduate research and internship programs that support diversity and inclusion;
  • Academic support programs (i.e., bridge programs, leadership development programs, tutorials, field experiences);
  • The development of metacognitive skills, scientific identity and attitudes, and self-efficacy of STEM students, particularly in the geoscience disciplines.

 

Although the COVID-19 pandemic upended and disrupted the completion of many of the articles that were started at the workshop, the following articles have either been submitted for peer-reviewed journal publication or are almost ready to do so:

 Title: Changing Geo Department Culture with Small Group Interventions: The Sparks for Change Pilot

Status:  Article ready for submission to Journal of Geoscience Education 

 

Title: Replicating Marginalization in Field Geology through Scientific Practice

Status: Article nearly ready for submission to Catalyst

 

Title: Measuring the Effects of Diverse Representation in STEM Classrooms

Status: Article under review at Communications Earth

 

Title: The Evolution of Student Engagement, Interest, and Perception of Geoscience During Challenge-Based Courses: Insights from the GeoFORCE Texas

Status: Article nearly ready for submission.  Target journal not specified.

 

The other articles are currently being completed with the hope of being submitted for publication in 2021.

 

The deliverables from this project will have transformative and sustainable effects on the geosciences. Not only did the project attract, add, and encourage a new cadre of geoscience experts to the geoscience writing and publication community, but it also increased and proliferated best practices for engaging URMs and other marginalized groups in the geosciences and thereby potentially will increase the successful participation of these neglected groups in the geosciences. By providing expert guidance in writing and submitting geoscience educational research papers to peer-reviewed journals, articles developed at the workshop will be widely disseminated. Moreover, by posting the articles on City Tech’s OpenLab site, the posted articles will be easily accessible to not only the geoscience community, but also to any group, institution, or persons across the globe who has an interest in cultivating diversity in the geosciences or in any other discipline. Some of the highlights of this project are its replicability, its adaptability, and its adoptability. The project may be scaled to involve more partners, more participants, and ultimately to produce more geoscience educational research articles that will help to inform how best to expand the geoscience tent as far as diversity and inclusion are concerned. Through this project, geoscience practitioners who perhaps never would have documented their work, primarily because of time constraints, were given an opportunity to do so.
